content.description:
Left of "Right Hand of The Leper: Your body will most likely be compacted into the small corner where you will match on two good crimps on the start of the 50° overhang.

 Beta Video: youtube.com/watch?v=m3uQu2w…;
content.protection: One pad, don't need a spotter, the landing is super clean!
content.location:
At Liberty Reservoir,  a very easy and short short approach:

 (1) Driving south from the intersection of Nicodemus Rd and Ivy Mill Rd, pull off to the side of the road to park: 39°26'09.7"N 76°52'12.9"W

 (2) Coming down south from the intersection, you should be able to see it from the road if there isn't any vegetation. Roughly the GPS Location: 39°26'10.9"N 76°52'16.4"W

 From the parking area mentioned in (1), you should be able to follow a trail system going northwest, follow the trail system for about 3-6 minutes until you see the obvious HUGE overhang rock that will be on the left side of the trail. Roughly around the GPS cords mentioned in (2).

content.description:
On the 50° overhang, two good crimps that allow solid thumb wraps and good feet for the start. Right hand throw to a crimp and adjust feet which may be a bit kilter. Video Beta: youtube.com/watch?v=d7lu7Rw… Then a throw to a jug slot left. Jug finish.

 A Maryland classic in the middle of bum frick nowhere, found by Tim Rose and FA by Fernando Jimenez who is a strong climber that has had bouldering sessions with Paul Robinson.
content.protection: 2 pads, don't need a spotter, the landing is super clean!
content.location:
At Liberty Reservoir,  a very easy and short short approach:

 (1) Driving south from the intersection of Nicodemus Rd and Ivy Mill Rd, pull off to the side of the road to park: 39°26'09.7"N 76°52'12.9"W

 (2) Coming down south from the intersection, you should be able to see it from the road if there isn't any vegetation. Roughly the GPS Location: 39°26'10.9"N 76°52'16.4"W

 From the parking area mentioned in (1), you should be able to follow a trail system going northwest, follow the trail system for about 3-6 minutes until you see the obvious HUGE overhang rock that will be on the left side of the trail. Roughly around the GPS cords mentioned in (2).

content.description: Huge reach. This boulder problem requires at least a six foot wingspan. You start on an undercling and then go to a crimp. From there you go past blank rock to the top of the boulder.
content.protection: Pad on the ground and the boulder behind the climb.
content.location: The route is on the Oakland Mill Boulder. It starts on a really nice undercling. Go to the ticked crimp and shoot for the top.

content.description: This is a simple V3 or V2. The top out is somewhat difficult because it is very dirty. The holds are very straight forward. It has a clear line of buckets to the top.
content.protection: A single pad on the ground should be fine. There is a small ledge you can fall off of, however it is more of a problem for spotters.
content.location: It is across from the pump house on a hill.

content.description: This route starts with an undercling and a foot on a flake that sticks out of the ground. The route then traverses a few feet to the right until you hit the end of the boulder. You then have to transition from an undercling to a top out. One of the easiest and most fun routes in the area.
content.protection: If you have a large midsection this boulder may not be for you. The deeper you go into the slot, the smaller the gap becomes. A ground pad and wall pad are recommended. Spotters won't do much because of the tight space.
content.location: Can be seen opposite the pump house. It is an open cave. There is no roof. it is one boulder stacked on top of the other boulder.

content.description:
This area is literally in the middle of nowhere. If you get injured that's going to be troublesome because of the enormous walk back to civilization. This area is somewhat underdeveloped. John Kelbel as well as myself have looked around the area. The boulders appear in clumps on large hills. Most of the time only one side of the boulder can be climbed, making the walk downs easy. Do not expect large boulders, most are just over seven feet tall. A few of the problems I have found amusing are extreme sit start boulders that require somewhat modern techniques. I would only go here if you have some way to easily access it. 

patapscorock.blogspot.com/

  This website has the location for some of the boulders. If you can find one, you're on a good start.
